Witco Sistersville RMP Executive Summary

1.  Introduction and Background

The Accidental Release Prevention (ARP) requirements mandated in Section 112r of the 1990 Clean Air Act Amendments were promulgated by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) on June 20, 1996.  These requirements are codified in 40 CFR 68, Subparts A through H.  Under the ARP program, processes with chemical quantities on site exceeding the listed threshold quantities have applicable requirements.

Witco Corporation produces silicone chemicals at the Sistersville plant.  As defined by the regulations, the Sistersville plant stores the following toxic chemicals in excess of the threshold quantities: anhydrous ammonia, acrylonitrile, ethylenediamine, propylene oxide, methyl chloride, 37% hydrochloric acid, methyltrichorosilane, dimethyldichorosilane and trimethylchlorosilane.  The plant stores the following flammable chemicals above threshold quantities as defined by the regulation: dimethylamine, and trichlorosilane.

The Witco Sistersville plant has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in safety and environmental protection, employee safety training, and safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of plant equipment.  Witco's written safety and environmental policy state that "Safety is unequivocally our number one priority".  Sistersville has implemented reasonable controls to prevent and mitigate probable releases of hazardous chemicals.  Should a release occur, trained personnel would respond to control and contain the release.     
    

2. Description of the Stationary Sources and Regulated Substances

Witco's Sistersville plant is a silicone chemical producing facility located at 3500 South State Route 2 in Friendly, West Virginia.  The plant is situated on approximately 1400 acres in southern Tyler County.  An environmental remediation firm and an aluminum dross-recycling firm to the south,

the Ohio River to the west, a rural residential area to the north and undeveloped forestland to the east occupy the immediate area surrounding the facility.

   Silicone chemicals have been manufactured at the facility since the mid-1950s.  Witco's Sistersville plant makes a variety of silicone products, which fall into three general categories: urethane additives, silicone fluids and silanes.  The products are utilized in a broad spectrum of industry.  The facility is operated 24 hours a day, seven days per week. Approximately 570 full time employees are at the site.  Plant manufacturing areas are broken down into four areas: Polymers I, Polymers II, New Product Development and Silanes.       


3. Worst Case release scenario and alternate release scenario.

The Risk Management Program (RMP) rule requires the development of accidental release scenarios for both the toxic and flammable chemicals at our site.

A worst-case scenario and alternate release scenario are designed to calculate
the potential impact to the surrounding community.  EPA defines a worst-case scenario as the complete release of the largest inventory of a chemical over ten minutes under weather conditions that would allow the chemical to travel the farthest distance at ground level.  It also assumes that none of the facility mechanical controls or safety systems is operational.  A worst-case scenario is highly unlikely to occur.

Given the severe guidelines of a worst-case scenario, more realistic alternate release or planning scenarios were also developed to more closely resemble a real world event.  These scenarios involve smaller releases and allow safety systems to be included in the release containment and dispersal calculations.  These alternate release scenarios are useful to local government and industry to prepare emergency response plans.

However, this scenario is highly unlikely to occur, as the tank is equipped with pressure safety relief devices should fire threaten to catastrophically rupture the vessel.  The vessel is also contained within a concrete secondary containment area; equipped with foam suppression systems and state of the art hydrolysis reactors to dispose of any material released. The tank level is continuously monitored by operator manned distributed control systems.



In addition, the vessel undergoes routine mechanical integrity inspections, which include both piping systems and unloading facilities.  The facility also maintains a fully trained fire brigade, available to respond to emergencies 24 hours a day.

Furthermore this scenario is unlikely to impact up to 13.1 miles as the plant will utilize the fire brigade and foam suppression systems to capture and minimize the release of methyltrichlorosilane, while contacting off-site responders if the release would impact off-site populations, as well as activating the local siren system to notify nearby residents.

The vessel is also contained within a concrete secondary containment area; equipped with foam suppression systems and state of the art hydrolysis reactors to dispose of any material released. General Accidental Release Prevention Program

    The Sistersville plant maintains a rigorous Process Safety Management program, which satisfies all applicable requirements of both OSHA's Process Safety Management Rule 29 CFR 1910.119 and EPA's Risk Management Rule 40 CFR 68. The facility maintains policies/programs, which address required program elements as follows:

Employee Participation- The facility encourages employees to participate in all facets of process safety and accident prevention programs.  Examples include participation in Process Hazard Analysis, operating procedure development, incident investigations, unsafe condition reporting, Central Safety team meetings, management of change reviews, etc.  

Process Safety Information- Process safety information is compiled prior to beginning any Process Hazard Analysis, Differential Process Hazard Analysis or  revalidation effort to assure proper documentation is available for review teams utilization during the Process Hazard Analysis process.  Process safety information is kept evergreen through the utilization of the management of change process as well as periodic internal and corporate audit verifications.

Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)- The facility maintains a procedure to assure PHA's and revalidations are conducted within prescribed timeframes.  DPHA's are conducted anytime a process or system has been modified significantly.  A management system is in place to document and track PHA actions to timely completion, assigning resources as needed to maintain demonstrable progress.

Operating Procedures- The facility maintains a procedure for construction of operating procedures, which i

ncludes all requirements specified by OSHA and EPA.  Annual reviews are conducted as required.  Operating procedures are reviewed and updated as required by the management of change process and through suggestions made by operators.

Training- The facility maintains a written and walkthrough training program for operations, maintenance and distribution personnel.  Facility personnel undergo training on OSHA, EPA and DOT required subjects on an ongoing basis.  Operations and maintenance personnel have received both overview training as well as specific process hazards overview training.  Refresher training is conducted every three years.

Contractors- The facility maintains a contractor qualification program, which meets all OSHA and EPA requirements.  Contractors receive hazard identification training prior to commencement of work and are monitored by the internal auditing program to assure compliance with all OSHA, EPA and Witco standards.

Pre-Startup Safety Reviews- The facility maintains an active program to perform pre-startup safety review on all changes to assure that all phases of the change have been installed correctly, personnel trained as required, and maintenance procedures are in place to safely maintain the equipment. 

Mechanical Integrity- The facility maintains an extensive mechanical integrity program, which covers not only regulated equipment but also all other equipment at the site.  Routine maintenance procedures are in place for critical equipment and tests required complying with PSM and RMP, following manufacturer recommendations.

Safe Work Practices- The facility maintains safe work practice policies, which govern hot work, confined space, master tag/lockout, and line breaking which meets or exceeds all OSHA and EPA requirements.  Compliance with these procedures is assured through the plants internal auditing processes, including internal audits, management walkthroughs, procedural audits, etc.

Management of Change- The facility maintain

ments of the management system of the accident prevent program in place to continue to improve safety throughout the facility.  The following elements of the PSM/RMP are used to improve safety:

    Management of Change (MOC)

s an active management of change process, which governs all changes made at time of the day or night in accordance with OSHA and EPA requirements.
      
Incident Investigation- The facility investigates all incidents and near misses in a timely fashion which meets or exceeds all OSHA and EPA requirements utilizing a multi-discipline team approach.  Management representative participates in incident reviews based upon the severity of the event.

Emergency Response- The facility maintains a trained emergency brigade on site 24 hours per day, seven days a week.  The facility has emergency plans and procedures in place and has communicated those with local regulating agencies. Mutual aid agreements exist with both neighboring communities and industrial entities in the region.

Compliance Audits- The facility undergoes qualifying process safety audits every 3 years in accordance with OSHA and EPA requirements.  Additional audits are performed on a periodic basis through the plants internal audit program.

Trade Secrets- The facility maintains a program to allow employees access to information considered as "trade secret" upon request of the employee.

Chemical Specific Prevention Steps-

    The facility maintains the ongoing integrity of the equipment through its mechanical integrity program.  Chemical processes are well documented through R&D Definitions of Technology, which are shared with operating departments prior to implementation of a new process.  

    Primary mitigation for hazard events is relief devices, water spray, foam protection and secondary containment.  

    Major process hazards identified by PHA teams are documented in mandatory Operational Safety Standards that define to operations the required mitigations to prevent hazardous situations.

    The facility has had no releases in the last five years, which meet the criteria for accidental release reporting as defined within 40 CFR 68.42.
